question: Which is not an effect of atropine?
exp: ANSWER: (C) Bradycardia. REF: KDT 4th Ed p. 94. EFFECTS OF ATROPINE: CNS* Stimulates medullary, vasomotor and respiratory center* Depresses vestibular excitation, hence anti motion sickness* Suppresses cholinergic activity in basal ganglia, hence decreases tremor.* High doses may cause cortical excitation, restlessness, disorientation and hallucinations. CVS* Tachycardia* Abbreviates A-V refractory period* Facilitates A-V conduction* No consistent effect on BPEYE* Mydriaisis* Abolition of light reflexes* Cycloplegia* Rise of IOTSmooth musdes* All visceral smooth muscles are relaxed* Constipation* Bronchodilation* Urinary retention* Urinary bladder and ureter relaxation* Effect on uterus is minimal* Effect of biliary tract is less marked. Glands* Decrease sweat, salivary, tracheobronchial and lachrymal secretions* Decreases secretion of acid and pepsin. Body temperature* rise. Local anesthetic* effect present

question: Most effective agent to prevent motion sickness is-
exp: Ans. is 'd' i. e., Hyoscine o Motion sickness is more easily prevented than cured. o Transdermal hyoscine (scopolamine) is the best agent for the prevention of motion sickness. o Antihistamines can also be used for prevention.

question: Drug of choice for belladoma poisoning -
exp: Ans. is 'b' i. e., Physostigmine o Physostigmine penetrates blood-brain barrier and antagonizes both central and peripheral actions of anticholinergics in acute anticholinergic poisoning (belladonna poisoning). About other optionso Neostigmine does not cross blood brain barrier. Thus it is ineffective for central anticholinergic actionso Tacrine is used for chronic central anti-cholinergic syndrome (Alzhiemer's disease).

question: Atropine is used in all EXCEPT:
exp: ANSWER: (A) Glaucoma. REF: KDT 5th edition p. 98. Uses of atropine * Preanaesthetic medication* Antispasmodic* Mydriatic* Cycloplegic* Vagolytic* Belladonna poisoning. Contraindications of atropine:* Narrow angle glaucoma* BPH

question: Anticholinergics cause all except-
exp: Ans. is 'c' i. e., Bronchoconstrction CNSo Atropine has an overall CNS stimulant action, while Hyoseine produces CNS depression, o Due to its amnestic and CNS depressant action, hyoseine induces "twilight sleep " and has been used as lie detector or truth serum in suspects. o Atropine stimulates medullary centres - vagal, respiratory, vasomotor, o Atropine depresses vestibular excitation and has anti motion sickness property. o Transdermal patch of scopolamine (hyoseine), applied behind the pinna is used to prevent motion sickness. o Atropine suppresses tremor and rigidity of parkinsonism by blocking relative cholinergic overactivity in basal ganglia. o Central cholinergic agents like benztropine, benzhexol (trihexiphenidyl) and biperiden are drug of choice for drug induced parkinsonism. CVSo The most prominent effect of atropine is to cause tachycardia. o On im/sc injection transient initial bradycardia often occurs due to blockade of muscarinic autoreceptors (Ml) on vagal nerve endings augmenting ACH release. o Atropine abbrevates refractory period of A-V node and facilitates A-V conduction, PR interval is shortened, o Atropine does not have any consistent or marked effect on BP. o Atropine can be used in arrhythmias like AV block and digitalis induced arrhythmia. Eyeo Atropine causes mydriasis, abolition of light reflex and cycloplegia (paralysis of accomodation), o Due to dilatation of iris, iris comes closer to angle of anterior chamber and trabecular meshwork at the base of ciliary muscle is closed - | aqueous out flow - | IOT. o Atropine increases intraocular tension - Contraindicated in glaucoma. Smooth muscleso Tone and amplitude of contractions of stomach and intestine are reduced, constipation may occur, o Atropine causes bronchodilatation and reduced airway resistance, especially in COPD and asthma patients, o Atropine relaxes urinary bladder, urinary retention may occur, o Effect on biliary tract is less marked and on uterus is minimal. Glandso Atropine decreases sweat, salivary, tracheobronchial and lacrimal secretion, o Atropine decreases secretion of acid, pepsin and mucus in the stomach, o Intestinal and pancreatic secretions are not significantly reduced, o Bile production is not affected. At higher doses atropine causes rise in body temperature --> Contraindicated in children due to risk of hyperthermia. Atropine has mild anaesthetic property on the cornea.

question: Atropine is added with diphenoxylate to:
exp: Ans: C (Decrease abuse potential) Ref: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, 2012, 12th Ed, Tala Mc. Graw hill, Katzung BG, Masters SB, Trevor AJ. P 1095. Explanation: Diphenoxylate is an opioid agonist without any analgesic property. It has Antimotilitv action hence it is used in non-infective diarrhoea. It can cause drug dependence since it has CNS effects. Atropine in small doses (0. 025 mg) is added with diphenoxylate 2. 5 mg to discourage overdose since this may cause atropine side effects which unpleasant

question: Mechanism of action of Oxybutynin?
exp: Ans. (b) Anticholinergic. Ref. KDT 6th ed. /107; Katzung Pharma 10th ed. Ch 8 MOA oxybutynin - cholinergic-muscarinic receptor antagonist* Oxybutynin is a selective M3 receptor blocker, used to relieve bladder spasm after urologic surgery, eg, prostatectomy. It is also used to relieve urinary and bladder difficulties, including frequent urination and inability to control urination, by decreasing muscle spasms of the bladder.* It competitively antagonizes the M3 subtypes of the muscarinic acetylcholine receptor.* M3 receptor blockers: (Mn: SOFT bla. Dar)# Solifenacin, Oxybutynin, Flavoxate, Tolterodine and Darifenacin

question: Spasmolytic analgesic is -
exp: Ans. is 'a' i. e., Dicyclomineo Antispasmodic (spasmolytic) drugs are used in various colic (pain) e. g. abdominal colic or renal colic, o Among the given options, dicyclomine is spasmolytic. Antispasmodic drugsi) Quaternary compounds - Propantheline, Oxyphenonium, Clidinium, Pipenzolate, Methylbromide, Isopropamide, Glycopyrrolate. ii) Tertiary amines - Dicyclomine, Valethamate, Pirenzepine. iii) Vasoselective antispasmodic (drugs acting on urinary bladder) - Oxybutynin, Tolterodine, flavoxate. iv) Drotaverine
